description.text:
Create your own and delicious ravioli from now on !

Ravioli Maker V1 is easy to make. Download and print file. No additional assembly required.

For the dough:

200g flour
2 eggs
salt
1 tablespoon olive oil

Mix ingredients and knead well. Let rest the dough in the refrigerator for about 30 min and then roll the dough thin out.
Turn the Ravioli Maker for cutting out the dough . Place some filling (fewer is much better! ) onto the dough and fold it carefully.

Place the finished ravioli simply in hot water ( not boiling ) for about 4-5 minutes..

Done. Buon appetito

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Infill:

25%

title: Pool Cue Holder/Stand/Rest - The FUCUE
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Behold, the FUCUE. It allows up to 3 cues to rest against a table, and fits in the accessory pouch/pocket on my cue case.

Inspired by this thing, and similar ones I've seen used at the pool hall, I designed my own version in TinkerCAD. I've included a blank version here in case our senses of humor do not align. Brand it however you like!

Printer:

Makerfarm Prusa i3v

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

50%

Notes:

I made it denser than I normally would, for some added weight (up to you though). Print it face down (180deg from model).

I used a needle file to round off the areas that make contact with the pool cue, and scuff up the rest of the surface for painting.

The bottom side will need some sort of grip for a slick table. I tried some hockey tape, but it was not grippy enough. I ended up plasti-dipping the whole thing which worked great. I applied 4 generous coats of the spray.

title: Kids Coat Rack “Animals”
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A nice coat rack for the kids for the nursery will teach kids to keep a little order. It might be easier if the child likes the animals on this rack. The construction is pretty straight forward but nonetheless very sturdy.

This build was done on a desktop cnc-machine from Stepcraft from approx 11 mm beech plywood using a spiral-toothed 3 mm flute.

Visit https://www.zenziwerken.de/en/ for more interesting designs.

I did a flimsy sketch and started to refine the details. Then I used Illustrator to trace the drawing an fitted the shapes on my material dimensions. Then I made a 3d-model to get an impression of the design- I used 3mm spiral flute because the length of the cutting edge is longer than my usual thin tools.

title: Quad Copter APM with modular system

description.text:
This is related to my http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:146849 modular system. My last quad crashed, ruining the frame and props, but the electronics were all fine.
This quad is based off .5 inch square dowels. The top is based off of my modular system, so the same components will connect, but I modified it to have screw holes that line up with the base. Due to bridging not leaving the flattest surface, I made the square dowel holes in the components taller to prevent needing a lot of cleanup when a part needs to be replaced.
The landing gear pieces are very thin, made to break as the weak point, but to be fast to print replacements. They can be placed in the center, like mine in the photos, or on the arms as the screw spacing is the same.
My frame only weighs 260 grams as seen in the attached photo. All up comes in at 920 grams w/ a 2200 lipo as flown in the video below.
My build is as follows:
one Quad Bottom
one Quad Base Top
four Landing Gear Arms
four Quad Arms (motor mounts)
one Battery Strap Base
Four ST2210 motors
Four 8045 props
One Qbrain 4x20 ESC
APM 2.5+ w/ GPS and power sensor
900Mhz Telemetry Module
FrSKY 4 channel CPPM receiver.
Maiden flight:
http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=7ptw4CZ74e0
I printed 20% infill ABS w/ 3 perimeters in slic3r.

Polyhymnia, Monte Calvo, 2nd century A.D., Marble, Nye Carlsberg Glyptotek (Copenhagen, Denmark). Made with Memento Beta.
The rotating movement emphasised by the right hand holding her cloak shows that the woman is dancing. She is Polyhymnia, the Muse of Dance.
Polyhymnia (“the one of many hymns”), also spelt Polymnia was in Greek mythology the Muse of sacred poetry, sacred hymn, dance, and eloquence as well as agriculture and pantomime. She is depicted as very serious, pensive and meditative, and often holding a finger to her mouth, dressed in a long cloak and veil and resting her elbow on a pillar. Polyhymnia is also sometimes credited as being the Muse of geometry and meditation. (Wikipedia)

description.text:
this lure swims very well. i have tested it in fresh water and have caught several nice sized large mouth bass with it. i printed it with black on the bottom and green glow pla on the top using the pause print at height plugin in cura to switch the filament. once again i used the smallest eye bolts from home depot and two number 4 treble hooks from bass pro.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/7QQ67PNoit0

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.1 mm recommended

Infill:

15

Notes:

a higher resolution will stop water from getting in to the lure and keep it floating better. i used cura as a slicer and set the pause plugin to pause near the tops of the cavities and added rattles (https://www.amazon.com/Fishing-Glass-Rattles-Insert-Attract/dp/B00NNV51D4) and weights. i used bird shot for the weights to give it a bit of extra rattle. but any weight that will fit in the holes will do. only add weights to the front and back vertical holes not the horizontal one in the middle that's where the rattles go. i put two in and just let them bang around.
Created as a token for Eldritch Moon Prerelease

author: superkid9

description.text: Based on Jetty's buzzer Support (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:16170), this hack uses a common household wireless doorbell system (instead of a piezo buzzer) so when your bot is done printing it triggers the receivers to chime throughout the house. I have two wireless receivers in different locations in the house linked to the makerbot. A different sound is triggered by the bot than by the actual doorbell (could be confusing otherwise!)

Installation will depend on what wireless doorbell system you can get hold of. I took apart the transmitter and discovered there was just a simple push switch in there, so easy to hack. The transmitter runs from 3v and the buzzer pin on the makerbot motherboard supplies 5v. Luckily the arduino mega has a 3.3v power output, so I just hooked that directly into the power of the transmitter. Since the makerbot motherboard buzzer pin supplies 5v, I hooked up the buzzer pin to the transmitter switch using a common 2N2222 transistor (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2N2222) and a 2Kohm resistor. I left the transmitter switch in place for easy testing.

title: z Brace for Wanhao Duplicator i3 PLUS

description.text:
As Wanhao has shortened the screws on the printer since the initial release, you will need longer screws.

UPDATED Sept 04, 2016
Added a channel for the metal frame to sit in to reduce movement even more.

A remix of Azza's "Z braces for Wanhao Duplicator i3, Cocoon Create, Maker Select, and Malyan M150 i3 3D printers."
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:921948

Just print the top_right, top_left and 6 of the balls from Azza's braces along with the 4 STL's from this remix to fit the i3 PLUS. Reuse the fasteners from the printer.

1mm to 1.2mm walls or 3 shells, and 50% infill @ 0.2mm layer height

M8 or 5/16" threaded rods ~420mm

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

title: Axiom 250 Quadcopter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Axiom is a quadcopter focused on three things: Durability, safety, and modularity. The interlocking shroud design is safer to fly, easy to print and the 250 mm quad size works on most printers. If you are a STEM educator, Axiom would make a great project for your classroom. It teaches important concepts in physics, engineering, and even computer programming while engaging students in the exciting fields of drones and 3D printing.

Instructions

Instructions for printing and assembling Axiom can be found here.

Recommended components

  • 2206 2000kv brushless motors (4)
  • 6x4.5 triple-blade props (2cw, 2ccw)
  • 30 Amp ESC's (or use motors with built-in ESCs) (4)
  • 1800 mAh 3S or 4S LiPo battery
  • Pixracer, Naze32, or other 36mm flight controller
  • FPV camera
  • Video transmitter (most sizes can be used)

Necessary hardware (screws, etc.) and printed parts for those without access to one can be purchased here.

Hardware:

  • Aluminum female-female hex standoff, M3 x 37, 4.5mm hex width (8)
  • M3 x 8 button head cap screws (40)
  • M3 nut (2)
  • No. 2 thread-forming screws (4)
  • Male-female nylon hex standoff, M3 x 10 (4)
  • Female-female hex standoff, M3 x 12 (4)
  • Zip tie, 4", narrow (8)
  • Zip tie, 8" (2)
  • Self-adhering Velcro strap, 280mm (1)
  • 2mm hex driver (1)

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

30%

Notes:

The propeller shrouds are designed to fit on any printer bed which is at least 7.8" wide. This includes Makerbots, Ultimakers, the Prusa i3, and lots of others. Just remember to disable rafts, skirts, and brims which can increase the build footprint and it should fit easily.

The recommended material for this design is ABS but PLA has also been used successfully. Just be careful about motor temperatures as they can reach levels that will soften the PLA enough to allow the motor screws to loosen.

All STL files are oriented for optimal surface finish and minimal supports. Many of them can be printed with little or no support, so feel free to test your printer and experiment.

This design prints well (and fast!) with oversize nozzles. You can use a 0.75mm nozzle with 0.4mm layer thickness and get great results. Standard size nozzles will work fine too though, and can create thinner walls for reduced weight.

comments.text: Your printer looks like it should work, but as always with a large ABS print like this warping/bed adhesion is the biggest concern. You're probably doing this already but for maximum adhesion, do not use the cooling fan, heat your bed to 110ºC, and print your first layer at 30-50% of your normal speed and 80-90% of your normal layer height to create more contact with the build surface. I also built a polycarbonate enclosure for mine but in a pinch you could just put a large cardboard box over your printer with a plastic wrap window to keep an eye on things. Obviously, take all due precautions to avoid creating a fire hazard.
comments.author: marcclaesson

comments.author: jsnodgrass

comments.text: It could take that long if you're printing slowly with fine layer resolution. It only takes me 2.5 hours but I have a high volume .75mm nozzle and I print with 400 micron layer heights. With a more typical setup 250 micron layers are fine and should speed things up a lot. Fine layer resolution isn't needed for this build.

comments.author: jsnodgrass

comments.text: That's disappointing Marc! It sounds to me like you probably do need some way to trap the heat from your printer or at least a warmer or less drafty location for it. An enclosure is probably the best answer. My first enclosure for my printer was the box that it came in with a flap cut out of the side like a door. I just put it over the top of the printer with the bottom open. It wasn't pretty but it reached 37C from the printer's own heat and allowed me to print large objects in ABS in a 20C basement.  A PVC pipe frame with plastic wrap walls would also be a cost-effective solution. The idea is just to build a tiny greenhouse around your printer to trap the heat.

description.text: Here are three puzzles made of 6 pieces that can be assembled into a cube. The puzzles are based on a 3x3x3 cube composed of 27 subcubes. and have three pieces of 4 subcubes and three pieces of 5 subcubes. OpenSCAD code is included.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator (5th Generation)

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

0.3 mm

Two of the puzzles have two sets of three identical pieces adding a pleasing degree of symmetry to the puzzles. A third puzzle allows a single piece to differ making the puzzle more difficult to solve. A brief discussion of the searches leading to the puzzles is included in the openSCAD code. Two randomly generated puzzles, 11 and 12, are last minute additions.

description.text:
Hi my name is Zander, for the last few weeks iv built three model rockets using 3D Printing. Why? Because rockets are incredibly cool! This is the third revision and the first public version. The rocket uses 1 C6-7 Rocket Motor. This rocket does not need any superglue unless you add a parachute, or Glue the motor to the engine compartment and the EC to the Body tube(Adds more safety and makes the craft more rigid Recommended). The craft fly's very stable at high speeds. The Center of mass is also quite low which means you can put weight anywhere above the Engine Compartment without messing it up, and giving the rocket even better flight characteristics! So feel free to stick in a parachute and some altimeters and have fun!

BTW the circuit diagram is for a igniter if you are interested. I left out resistor values for the led is 360Ohm.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa I3

Rafts:

Yes

Resolution:

0.25

Infill:

25% for Engine Compartment 100% for everything else

Notes:

I will be adding different size engine compartments for different motors, so please make your best judgement when choosing infill for them.

Finishing

Some sanding/gluing may be needed for lose or very tight clearances.

When designing this rocket I used autodesk Inventor 2017, A calculator, and lots of google. The fins are large to put the center of mass above the center of pressure because having the cop above the com makes the rocket unstable and the rocket will almost certainly fly with a dangerous unpredictable flight path. I also took into the consideration engine sizes with my engine compartment so that a larger or smaller motor may be used if needed.

How to calculate the heighth of a rocket using Trigonomatry

Here is a video to help you understand how to calculate the height of the rocket. You will need a Tape Measure, and a moveable Protractor with a sight.

description.text: My wife is making a coat rack and she wanted something to hide the screws of the hooks she is using. Derived from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:48076 . Printed in ABS @ .3mm with 15% infill and support.

Keep your Mantis Claw safe and secure, for travel or just on your shelf!

title: Puppy wheelchair with extra 'leg' and larger wheels and longer cradle

description.text:
This is a remix of DIACOV's puppy wheelchair (small).
I changed the wheels (used wheels off another design I had on hand, then laid them 3 thick and increased the size by 125%) I also trimmed, added and thickened the cradle I made it about 3cm longer and doubled the thickness by simply copying it and laying it on top of the old design. I am sure there are better ways of doing it but I am not a designer so this is the best I could come up with.
I added the training wheel part 'extra 2.0' to add the additional wheel to support the puppy because it had trouble balancing and caused some back stress.

Printer:

CTC

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.1

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I only used support/rafts on the rod and cradle and arc.
This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1249862 but I could not upload it as a remix. All credit goes to DIACOV for the initial design, they did a fantastic job.
To assemble, I used m3's to attach the cradle to the rod, then m5 or m6 to attach the wheels and added leg to the rod/arc. Cant remember which but I literally took the modle to the hardware store to pick the right bolts

comments.text: This looks like a great design.  I'm currently printing it out and I'm wondering how you attached the wheels?  Did you use bearings or slide the wheels directly over the shaft?
comments.author: BienAgiter

comments.text:
Been a while since I did it, I think I just used M4's with double washers and double nuts on the end so they wouldnt undo. Think I even added glue to the double nuts just for self assurance.
For the middle it was the M4 with a washer, through the plastic to another washer, then wheel, then washer, then through the other side of the plastic, then washer and 2 nuts. For the outer wheels I think I put two washers either side of the wheel, single washer on the outside of the cradle and double nuts.
It was all I had on hand at the time and it worked great for me.

description.text:
This is a 40mm fan adapter for the E3D Chimera cold end and 40mm fan grill.

I wanted a quieter solution to the 30mm fan included with the Chimera kit from e3d. There are other adapters out there, but I wanted a more robust and refined solution. This adapter attaches to the top two mount points on the Chimera heatsink with two M3 socket head cap screws.

Hardware needed:
2x M3 Socket Head Cap Screw, 8mm or 10mm
4x M3 Socket Head Cap Screw, (thickness of your 40mm fan)+10mm
(I used 30mm screws, since my fan was 20mm thick)

Make sure you pre-fit the M3 screws in the heatsink to thread the channels. They're a pretty tight fit, but that makes for a really sturdy result. I've included the F360 files for anyone who wants to tweak the designs.

I designed these parts for my Voron 3d printer build.

description.text:
Easy pusher motor mount for your RC plane. This can be mounted in the pusher or tractor orientation.

Motor mount for brush-less RC motors to foam or wood model bodies. The motor hole pattern is the standard 16 x 19mm -- such as the popular 2212 - 2200kv motor.

The files included show two different versions of the mount. The plus has added surface area for more secure mounting and to help distribute the energy over a wider area. The bottom mounting plate has two options -- solid or with a hole for less weight.

Recommended:
4 - 3mm x 6mm motor mounting bolts

title: LED Light Clip for Rostock max / Orion printers

description.text:
This is a LED clip that attaches to the base of the extruded aluminum of the seemecnc rostock max and Orion 3d printers. The clip portion of this, really works well. The problem is that the effector can collide with this light if you are printing something big.

The light clip is designed for 5mm LEDs. I used the 50pcs Mixed Colour 5mm Leds Pre Wired Light 12v 20cm Bulb found here: https://amzn.com/B00PI2SWZA

I drilled a small hole to allow the Wires to go directly into the cabinet of the printer.

The light flickers when you are printing directly to the power supply. to solve this I added a DROK® DC Step Down Variable Voltage Regulaor 36V to 24V 12V 5V 3.3V 3V Buck Converter Electronic Volt Stabilizer Car Automatic Battery Adjustable Regulated Power Supply DIY LM2596 Module Board. http://smile.amazon.com/dp/B00VUHVX6W.
Now there is no more flicker.

Lastly, I didn't want this thing ALWAYS on when I'm printing, so... I added something like http://smile.amazon.com/dp/B012IJ3DZY. (although mine was different)

I mounted the toggle in a mirror image of the power switch near the Y tower. lets face it, asymmetry of the power switch bothers you a bit.

Good Luck!

author: Kumardebu

description.text:
Modeled this matrix in SketchUp for finding the right setup and settings on my B9Creator, DLP 3D printer, when I mix resins or add colours, calibrate projector, etc. It's very small, fast 4-5 minute print, and has alot of features that help me choose the right exposure times, etc.
I didn't have much room for text so I coded the hints as compact as I could, to help remember the features. Here's what they mean: Cylinders: Diameters 1mm - 0.1mm Tubes: Hole diameter. 1mm - 0.1mm (there are 2 rows with different wall thickness) Cylinders large: H=height increments of 0.1mm starting at 3mm; >diamenter< by increments of 0.1mm Cubes: H=height by increments of 0.05mm; < distance between > by increments of 0.1mm; >width< by increments of 0.1mm Walls: from 1mm to 0.05mm thick, by increments of 0.05mm Comb: wall thickness and space between from 1mm and thinner by increments of 0.1mm; Angles by increments of 5° So depending on material used, pigmentation and what dimensions are more critical in what I need to print, I print this matrix first and look at external or internal dimensions to gage the right parameters. For example, if I need to achieve thin walls I look at the Walls
section and see what is the thinnest wall that printed well; if I need to achieve thin channels I look at distance between features or the Comb, what is the shortest distance between features that came out clean without cured resin; If I'm not sure how thick to slice (the B9C printer Z mechanism has 6.35 micron steps) to match the exact height in the model if it's critical....etc, and adjust printing parameters accordingly, I print another matrix to make sure and when I have it right I print my object.
Voilà, have more fun!

comments.text: Hey BDan, can you elaborate on what the numbers near each item represent? Some I understand to be distance between objects or heights, but specific info would be helpful!
comments.author: rkundla

comments.text: Thanks, I'll put this in the main description
comments.author: rkundla

comments.text: Thanks much! That really helps me understand better what I am looking at or should be looking for when I print it. :-D
comments.author: BDan

comments.text: I'm using the B9Creator. Its a resin-based printer that hardens liquid material with light from a projector. The projector is low rez but we get a 50µm pixels for small and precise stuff and 100µm pixels for bigger stuf. Or 75µm pixels if you need a 150µm feature on a bigger object...
comments.author: BDan

comments.text: which printer are you using?
comments.author: secretgspot

comments.text:
Are there anywhere samples to use for ROSTOCK-MAX and some explanation what to try if some stuff looks a certain way and it should look differently ... etc?
For most I am very happy with my printer (I am new to this 3D world...) but I like to print so good, it must be perfect all the time. I know that would be very hard to achieve, but I must try to have my printer setup very perfect I can.
Thanks for all of your help guys! Tony
comments.author: czecht

comments.text:
We can have a discussion about this thing here.
This clear rubbery material I'm trying is Spot-e(lastic), it's fantastic for crispness because there's no scatering of the light by prticles in the way, light shines straight through, but it shines deep and even comes back so it will block (cure) your cavities. It's also good because it really sticks to the Build Table like a totoo, no warping, no failed prints.

description.text: After I printed and installed TechShopJim's Official TechShop Filament Guide (Thing # 16499) I discovered that with my spool mounted in the left of my TOM, the filament kept popping free of the tip. A little bit of mirroring and the problem was solved!

Just like the original:
1.) Print it out,
2.) Bolt it on to the top of your MakerBot using two machine screws and nuts,
3.) Snap the filament throught the slot in the side of the guide channel,
4.) Enjoy trouble-free feeding!

print_settings.Notes:: You can print this with any settings you like but the one in the photo was done in ABS at 0.2mm 20%

description.text:
My wife wanted something to holder lipsticks upright in a drawn so she could see the colour lables. shes sketched this design on paper for me. I drew it up and printed it.

The design allows for 9 items of upto 30mm in diameter to be held upright in a 3x3 grid.

I have included the 123D Design file so others can modify as they like.

NOTE: This this printed upside down to prevent need for supports.

print_settings.Notes:: Material used - PLA for all parts. I think that the softer ABS would be less satisfactory for most of the rotating parts which need to rotate freely. The exception is the pawl which shouldn't be too 'bouncy'. I made the pawl in PLA, but a softer grade - Polymaker's PolyMax. Note that I changed to this fairly early in the development phase and it's possible the latest design which allow for the fitting of 3mm screws to fine tune the weight of the pawl may mean that regular PLA would be OK. As I've mentioned above it's important to keep the parts flat and I found BuildTak helpful for this - especially as my Ultimaker Original does NOT have a heated build plate. On the wider parts I used a brim.

title: Galileo Pendulum clock Mk I - Updated

description.text:
This is an update of thing:1618843.
I've included all the files, not just the updated ones.
The update falls into three categories:

  1. To provide a larger operating window. The original design worked, but too much less that 100% of the time to be fully satisfactory. The major factors in getting good operation, given that the parts have been made (close to) flat, is that the pawl, and the pendulum assembly can rotate absolutely freely. To that end I've redesigned two support brackets and offer them with a selection of different size bores which are engraved on the side. These make assembly easier. I think that one bracket in each pair should be a neat fit to the shaft however I've found that it's impractical to expect the other bracket in the pair to also be a neat fit. For me the brackets marked 9.6 and 10.4 are the best ones.
    The other important change is to the peg stopper. I now offer several variants. The larger the number the more it lags that pawl lifter. The variants 2.5 and 4.5 are 0.5 mm longer than 3 and 4. For me 4.5 is the best one.
    As for the pawl.... I'm still of the view that a slightly softer grade of PLA (or ABS) is better that standard PLA as it will bounce less. However as an alternative I've designed pawls with holes in them to accept 3mm screws so that the head end can be made heavier. Not sure it helps - I don't need screws with my Polymaker's PolyMax pawl.
    Another change is an adjustable bracket to limit the starting position of the pendulum - this makes it easier, once set, to start the pendulum is a position most likely to work.
  2. To tune the tick interval to 'exactly' 1 second. To achieve this - without the whole thing become too tall - I've had to add a weight at the end of the pendulum. This has the effect of moving the centre of gravity of the pendulum further from the pivot point, without any increase in the overall length. Nonetheless I've had to make the unit a little taller to get to 1 second.
    A drawback of this approach is that the pendulum now requires more input energy so a heavier weight is needed. The weights that work for me are 80g for the pendulum and 702g for the weight (both include the bottle weight but not the bottle cap). I'm using lead fishing weights in a variety of sizes for best packing efficiency.
  3. To increase the time of operation. To this end the pendulum rod is now significantly offset so the weight can be brought up higher, and extension legs can be added to the (new) frame base. And extensions can be added to the extensions though I haven't done so s I think it would become too unstable. Presently I get around 2 1/4 minutes total time.

Not fitting in the above categories is a redesign of the caps to make them a looser fit on the bottles.

A video of the finished article in action is here:https://youtu.be/1_x9zGTSlHo

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20-40%

Notes:

Material used - PLA for all parts. I think that the softer ABS would be less satisfactory for most of the rotating parts which need to rotate freely. The exception is the pawl which shouldn't be too 'bouncy'. I made the pawl in PLA, but a softer grade - Polymaker's PolyMax. Note that I changed to this fairly early in the development phase and it's possible the latest design which allow for the fitting of 3mm screws to fine tune the weight of the pawl may mean that regular PLA would be OK. As I've mentioned above it's important to keep the parts flat and I found BuildTak helpful for this - especially as my Ultimaker Original does NOT have a heated build plate. On the wider parts I used a brim.

The design size I use for shafts and the holes in which they rotate is the same. eg 8mm for both. I rely on shrinkage to bring the shaft a little under 8mm and use a straight hand reamer to bring the holes very close to 8mm dead. I't would be a struggle with reamers, I think. (See Summary for info on larger bore brackets).
I also recommend a tapered reamer to open the start of holes intended for screws,
Talking of which, all screws are 3mm Button Head Caps Screws.
Those in the ratchet are 15mm long - 12-off.
The remaining screws are all 10mm long - about 40!
Also, you'll need lead shot (fishing weights) for the bottle weight and the pendulum bob. I used assorted sizes to get as much weight into the bottle as possible. Weight of bottle and lead (excluding the cap) - 80g for the bob and 702g for the weight.

I started with the photos of the metal models (I've uploaded those photos to thing:1618843) and went from there. All the design work was done in Moi (Moment of Inspiration). Once I had an escapement design I ran it as a simulation (unsuccessfully) in SimLab Composer Mechanical and refined the design until it would simulate. I've provided a link to that simulation in thing:1618843.
I cheated a little on the gear spacing. In the interest of making everything as 'free' as possible the gears are 1mm further apart than the intersection of their PCDs.

author: mgg942

description.text: As with all these awesome.PDO files on the internet. I have been working on a simplistic way of turning these really cool 3D helmets into wearable items. A little unorthodox but very simple, where by all I've done is use Windows 10 3D Builder to split the item into 8 separate .stl file/ pieces with the split function. Rotated them into the best printing position with as little overhang as possible. Making the shells anywhere between 4 - 6 and the infill at 10% - 20% I gathered that all that has to happen at the end is to dremel the waste product off and scrape out the infill which should leave a excellent shaped outer shell to then glue all the bits together leaving a perfect helmet reproduction. Well I started the idea today and have posted pics of the first 4 pieces. Now each piece uses approximately 500gms of plastic at just under 4kgs a helmet. Now most of that will be waste which can be reused or put to good use as acetone slurry. About $16.00 worth of plastic if your making your own filament. Good luck and enjoy ; )

title: Fridge Magnet On/Off Switch
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A handy magnet, that can be switched between on and off positions. Notes and photos can easily be removed without detaching the magnet from your fridge or board.

The OpenSCAD design is fully parametric, so different sizes, magnet cavities and wordings can be incorporated with minor changes. Supports are not needed, therefore it should be possible to print this thing on any 3D-printer easily.

See the switch in action: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ksh_C5nZZTU

UPDATE 2016-07-06: swapped positions of words on/off due to community feedback

Printer:

boXY

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.1mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

A lower resolution at 0.2mm works, too, but the backside will get a lot rougher. A high infill density is not needed due to low loads.

Insert the magnets

Put your magnets into the cavities on the backside. If they won't hold there due to low friction, use some drops of superglue to secure them.
Hint: You may use cylindrical magnets instead. They fit in the cubic holes, too.
Important: If you're using cube shaped magnets, be sure to use the right orientation. The poles should be facing up or down, not sideways. The poles can easily be identified by attaching to magnets with each other; they are on the side sticking together or pointing outwards.

Placing the magnets inside the cavities Glue the words

Use some drops of superglue to attach the letters on the front of your magnet. Tweezers may help no glueing your fingers together.

Using only little superglue will avoid ugly blobs

<iframe allowfullscreen="None" frameborder="0" src="https://www.youtube.com/embed/ksh_C5nZZTU" ></iframe>
Switching the magnet is easy

Parts used (BOM):
  • 1x magnetic switch (printed)
  • 1x letters (printed)
  • 2x magnets (cube 5x5x5mm or cylndrical D5x5mm)
Tools used:
  • Tweezers
  • Superglue

description.text: This is a rotating joint for creating lamps with EL wire and clear 1/4" acrylic tubes.

Use a low-profile m3 nut and bolt through the centerhole to and tighten when you decide on the angle you want.  Cut 1/" acrylic tubes to the lengths you want and link them together with as many joints as you want for your design.  Run the EL wire through the acrylic and around the joints being careful not to bend the wire too sharp.  Tighten the m3 nut and bolt on every joint to keep your design rigid, then turn on the EL wire!

description.text:
UPDATE: 2 (3 actually) really key bits: Added hex shafts so things can actually turn on it, and added a little snap-y thing so that when closed the balls won't fall out. The snap bit is a little big, I filed it down, but as I only need one I didn't bother tweaking the file.

I needed a thrust bearing type thing for the gyro/pendulum/hamster in my Lego BB-8.

I had bought a small bearing, but decided it wouldn't work, and I have some 1/4" Acetal balls lying around, so I decided to make an upper & lower race for them.

It's hard to see this at work, so I made a video of them spinning: https://youtu.be/8dvflMZPUWg, and another which doesn't help much: https://youtu.be/s5WQSzcg234 - feel free to visit the advertisers to support my things :)

The load is intended to be over the balls. Loads on the end of the upper ring will cause it to rub on the bottom. The bottom race's inner wall is lower and the upper race's outer wall is shorter. My thinking is that maybe the balls get shoved to the outside and the top gets shoved toward the center. Not sure if that actually happens though, may have needed more oval of a cross section for that.

You'll need about 19 Acetal (Delrin) 1/4" bearings. The race is slightly larger which worked well for me with my printer error, however you may need to scale it slightly (very slightly). You don't want the race completely packed with bearings, 18 or 19 is probably good.

I bought bearings from McMaster-Carr

Printer:

FlashForge

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.2mm (Standard)

Infill:

20% (expecting a load) / 4 shells

Notes:

Both of the STL's are upside down to how you would want to print them, sorry.

This is not intended to be useful as-is. Though it might work if you needed. The bottom race is designed to fit in a hole in a board, but I expect most folks will want to modify the sketchup files or mix them into more useful housings.

Indeed, the top is just to test that it works, my real part will be more complex for my needs.

Mine had a nice small gap, however if yours rub you may want to modify the files to trim some of the lips.

I had to file the lip of snap on the top one so that it could snap into the bottom because it was a little big. That ridge is just to keep it from falling apart accidentally.

The joiner on my daughters Tinkerbell bag broke. This is the replacement I came up with. The pin didn't print very well for me. Probably would have been a better idea to lay it on it's side. Was almost impossible to get to slide in the hole. The bar, is a bit on the thin side, but it made it easier to slide in. Probably put some good gorilla glue on it once you know it will fit. I'm including the source code from openscad so you improve on the design if you wish to make one.   
Oops almost forgot a little explanation. The bag had two strapping loops. Both were permanently attached, so you couldn't take the strap loose and string it through a clasp of some sort. That's why I designed the bar and the peg. Just insert the strap up into the housing, and push the peg/bar through the loop, so it holds the strap in place. Depending how much stuff you keep in your bag, the peg could be replaced with a screw and a nut.
happy printing!

(for each axis - so double this)

description.text: Are you tired of having a bunch of papers on your desk? Make sure the most important one is visible at all the times. This paper holder gives you freedom to hold a document in an upright position. I love using it when I am working along side the computer, allowing me to look at the screen and the document at the same time.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Supports and rafts are not necessary.

Printing time: 1 hour
Paper Holder with vertical paper setup. Smooth design makes it easy to slide the paper in.

A simple holder for a simple job

Call me old fashioned but there are some documents that I prefer to read in physical form. I like the feeling of turning the page and looking at the physical paper. Now, with this comes the disadvantages of paper, the cluster of having documents and documents shuffling each other as I read and search for specific pages.

To avoid this I designed this paper holder. With it, I can highlight a document I'm working on and have it along side my monitor. I always work in front of my computer, so this is perfect to integrate paper and screen.

I tried to design something I would like to have in my desk. A simple design which blends with the office supplies and at the same time gets the job done. The slit bends the paper to make it stand upright, eliminating the need for any vertical supports from the holder. The bottom of the holder is slightly angled, making it easier to read the document.

Let me know if you print the paper holder and if I should improve the design.

comments.text: This worked great for holding important bills or now for the family. I scaled it up to 1.6x to hold multiple papers and envelopes.

title: Angry Bird
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
To pose myselft the challenge to create an object that is assembled from separate components in different colours of PLA, I started designing an angry bird ... from scratch in FreeCAD. Although I'm still not completely happy about how the components fit together, I'm quite proud I was able to make the design based solely on a couple of 2D representations from the game.

Angry Birds is a trademark of Rovio Entertainment Ltd., to which I am not affiliated.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker Original

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I did use supports on the tail, the brows, the bottom and the body, because I was not sure whether the overhangs would be handled correctly. You can prevent using supports by conveniently placing the objects on your build plate, however, I still recommend supports for the body.

The colours of PLA I used:

  • body: Ultimate Red
  • bottom: Ultimate White
  • beak: Ultimate Yellow
  • brows: Performa Black
  • eyes: Ultimate White
  • tail: Performa Black
I glued all items together (they don't 'click' together) with some two component epoxy.

FreeCAD & Meshmixer operations

Next to the challenge of designing an assembled object, it required some very creative thinking, estimating sizes & positions, and CSG (constructive solid geometry) operations. I primarily used sketches, pad & revolve from the Part Design workbench to create objects. The CSG operations in the Part workbench were used to make the cutouts (negative spaces if you will) for objects to fit in. The head feathers (or comb?) were most difficult. They were done by drawing basic 2D shapes in the Draft workbench and the loft-operation in the Part workbench. Then I ended up with flat ends (as you can see in the FreeCAD design), but they were easily rounded off by exporting the STL, loading it into Meshmixer and using Sculpt operations to remove the sharp edges.

I've gone away on trips, only to come home to empty or withered pots of plants. If you're a primary gardener and need to entrust someone with your plants, especially when you have a range of watering needs, here's some help.

The watering indicators come in half, light, heavy and through ("go ahead, you can't drown it") markings. Simply decide how much water is needed for each level and your plants should be safe.

Need to water some of the plants twice a day? Simply print the icons in two different colours, so two pegs mean water twice a day as scheduled.

Have fun, save your plants.

title: ORBZ -  A mutli-layerd orb shaped storage solution
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
'ORBZ' are a unique and stylish orb shaped storage solution for small things. There are three storage compartments and each layer separates to allow access to the lower layers storage area. Rotate the layers back to the aligned position to close your 'ORBZ' back into an intriguing, attention grabbing display piece that draws attention... what's inside???.

At standard scale 'ORBZ' measure 75mm diameter fully assembled. The clearances designed in have been set to make this assemble without issues on most machines however with highly accurate machines / slicing apps they can be uniformly reduced in size by up to 10% if required (which will tighten clearances).. They should be able to be can be uniformly scaled up if you want greater storage capacity.

The layers are all different depths in order to accommodate a broad range of different sized small things... just place your items inside and close it up. 'ORBZ' have a flat base so are stable and stand well. However, they are not designed to stand when opened but will in some instances depending on the weight and placement of items inside.

'ORBZ' primary purpose ids to store small things inside take things and be closed up so they become a display piece. This makes them both practical and fun to have at home, at work in your office, in your workshop or classroom.

'ORBZ' are should be straight forward and easy prints on most machines. They look great in almost any color... or you could have different colors for different layers if you want. Print some for yourself or use them as a unique and fun gift.

Please refer to the print settings provided and images for additional information. Raft is recommended for the base layer (Layer 4) to increase build plate adhesion on the part with the smallest contact area.

...and when you print some 'ORBZ' please post images for others to see!

Note: If you like this check out the rest of my practical and fun designs.

Refer to the images provide for assembly instructions.

The hole in the base of each layer slides over the pin on the layer below it when rotated 180 degrees from that layer. Rotate the top layer to align with the layer below it to close the lower layer storage compartment.

Assembly is a quick and easy process and layers can be separated at any time by reversing the process (i.e. Rotate to 180 degrees from the layer below and lift apart).

comments.author: puprock

comments.text: Sorry to hear you're having issue's with the base part.  The deformation you are referring to will be  due to the quite extreme angle applied at the bottom of the base... but it needs to be that angle to be a round object. The design actually features a small flat base reduced angle to make it print reasonably for most people  with a well set up PLA machine with a filament fan. The filament fan makes the filament solidify almost immediately after being extruded. This is what lets you print out on extreme angles.  However, not all machines have a filament fan and / or an 'effective' fan. Some blow more directly than others... the next thing is the Fila entry fan setting in u our slicing app. If its set too low it won't cool well enough to deal with angles like this. I don't greatly suffer from this issue with my MakerBot's as the fan outlet is close / direct and it runs at 50% force. Hopefully this helps you improve your result...

I picked up one of these at a game store called Funco Land in Colma California back in like 1999? Didn't get the light bar you need to make it work, ended up disassembling it, rigging it with EL Wire, resin-casting copies of the body, and giving it away to a friend...I may have made some suboptimal life choices.

But now you can all 3D Print your own!

Update 10/30/2016
I've got the main body up (and the rubber bits); "studless" has no screw studs, "sewable" has a series of perforations along the bottom so it can be sewn directly to a glove or sleeve of your choice. Note that the screw holes don't line up on the bottom - mirroring the STL file and extending out the bottom would probably fix that, feel free to remix that if you're interested - I can't even figure out which studs were for holding on the circuitboard and which ones were screws that held the whole thing together, at this point.

Final? Update 2017-01-24

All pieces now exist. Extensive purpose-driven mods will be needed beyond this point. If I ever get around to making myself one, I'll update accordingly.

At least one of the backhands is backwards. The bottom, I think. Use the mirror function in your slicer as needed; I'm probably making a lefty anyway, because why on earth did they expect us to game proficiently one-handed, left-handed, on the back of our right forearm?

description.text:
I need to print a lot of MineCraft figures, for a diorama, so I needed to simplify the Steve's (OpenSCAD) design. The changes are:
  • Arranged Steve as a single piece to print, so no assembling and gluing Steve's head, arms and legs on.
  • Added parameters for Customizer to control scale, head angle, and position ("running" or "working"). Since you can't position him manually, you can do so in software.
  • Added "feet" so that you can tell which way he's facing
    • After printing Steve, you will need to trim off supports under each shoulder.

To generate the Steve you want:
  • Pick a scale. 1.5 mm/pixel works out to 1" MineCraft cubes, good for a large diorama. 5 mm/pixel is good for an action figure.
  • Enter a head angle. 0 means looking straight ahead.
  • Pick a position. "Run" means that arms and lets are angled like Steve is running. "Work" means that Steve is standing and using a tool. "Custom" means that you can control the angles of the arms and legs individually.
    • If you pick "custom" you can then set:
  • Leg angle: the angle that the legs are away from vertical. 0 means Steve is standing, 45 means he's running full-speed. -15 would be walking, with the right leg behind the left. The left and right legs are always in opposite positions, so Steve can stand up.
  • Left Arm Angle: 45 means out in front, 0 means straight down, etc. Don't use an angle more than 45 degrees or you'll probably run into overhang issues.
  • Right Arm Angle: Same as above, for the arm that hold tools.
    • Generate and print. Trim off the supports under Steve's shoulders. Print tools, widely available on Thingiverse. Or go out for drinks, and get Steve a sword or an umbrella!

comments.text: Yeah, the print quality isn't great - I really pushed speed up, to see how fast I could crank it, and I went a bit too far. Printing at more reasonable speeds, Steve looks fine!

description.text:
Pisara, a plywood basket for firewood logs, for sauna or other indoors fireplace, height 52 cm, width 37 cm, depth 28 cm. Designed by Olli Niemitalo and Outi Lampela in Finland and released under the Creative Commons Attribution license.

Materials and tools required:

  • 4 mm 3-ply birch plywood without too many knots, no surface treatment, 960 mm x 560 mm, with top and bottom grain oriented parallel to the shorter side. Better add a few cm safety margin to the given dimensions but make sure the piece fits your printer.
  • Wood glue, polyvinyl acetate (PVA).
  • 32 mm (or 30 mm) natural fiber tape (cotton, linen etc.), strong, 3 m.
  • Sisal string or similar, approx 50 g, 13 m. It must be thin enough to go through a 5 mm diameter hole in the plywood. If you choose a soft variety the handle will feel nicer.
  • Heavy duty cotton string for embroidery (light green is a nice color). You won't need much, 1 m is plenty.
  • Heavy duty needle for embroidery. Must go through a 3 mm diameter hole in the plywood.

Notes:

The file pisara20.pdf is ready for printing to the laser cutter from Acrobat Reader. I used the Epilog Laser Fusion laser cutter of FabLab Oulu on 4 mm birch plywood with these settings: Resolution: 600 dpi. Default settings: CO2. Job type: vector. Vector setting: Speed 5 %, Power 100 %, Freq 30 %, Power comp. enabled. The cutting time was about 32 minutes. Please observe the correct top and bottom surface grain orientation per assembly instructions image.

The top of each piece (as they were cut) will be the outside face. You don't need to glue any of the plywood pieces together. Follow the numbers in the assembly instructions image together with these identically numbered instructions:

  1. Set the main plywood pieces on a table so that their bottoms connect. Make sure that they are not upside down because then the joint at the top wont work when they are bent later.
  2. Glue the fabric tapes onto the sides of the top side of the main pieces leaving an overhang of approximately 7 cm at each end. Also leave without glue approx 10 cm from the top of the plywood. Allow the glue set for at least 10 minutes.
  3. Insert the round-ended strips into the holes of the main pieces, so that they come out at the same side as the fabric tape. You will need to bend the main pieces a bit and use force. Make sure that the strips are centered.
  4. Put the main pieces on top of the bottom piece. The fabric tape should now be sandwiched between the main pieces and the bottom piece.
  5. Insert one end of a P-like support piece through the hole in the bottom piece and in the round-ended strip. Repeat this with the other P-like support piece.
  6. Insert both parts of a small locking piece through the hole in the P-like support piece. You may need to use a bit of force to squeeze the bottom and the round-ended strip together, making the hole visible. Repeat this with the other bottom support piece. Turn the P-like support piece to insert its other end also through holes in the bottom piece and the round-ended strip. Make sure that everything is centered and use plenty of force to squeeze the bottom and the round-ended strip together and insert both parts of a locking piece through the P-like support piece. Repeat this with the other bottom support piece. Push with quite a bit of force the four rectangular locking mechanisms built in into the bottom piece so that they click in place, preventing misalignment of the basket parts.
  7. Bend the main pieces to a teardrop shape forming the joints at the top. Lock the pieces together by the handle using the Pac-Man-like assembly tools so that it is easier to work on them. Slide the Pac-Man-like tools to the ends of the handle. Trim to a nice length and glue the remaining ends of the fabric tapes to the plywood and to each other. Let the glue set for at least 10 minutes after which you can remove the Pac-Man like assembly tools and work more easily.
  8. Insert the jagged square pieces to the holes near the center in the two parts of the handle already in place.
  9. Insert the piece with a large hole to the holes near the ends in the two parts of the handle already in place.
  10. Insert the remaining pieces of handle.
  11. You will use the Domino-like pieces at the end of this step. Insert one end of the sisal string into the round hole in the handle and fish it out through the end by the hook tool. Make a knot about 15 cm from the end of the handle and pull the not into the handle. Wrap the string around the handle tightly. Ask someone to help and move the roll while you do the wrapping. When you have reached the round hole at the other end of the handle, cut it leaving a 15 cm overhang that you push through the round hole and fish it out at the end of the handle using the hook tool. Push it back and forth through the holes in the domino piece and make a knot so that the domino piece is already very close to the handle. Push the dangling end of the string into the handle. Rotate the domino piece so
    that the string tightens and pulls the domino piece into the handle. Repeat this at the other end of the handle.
  12. (This number is not in the image.) Do an embroidery that together with the existing glue attaches the end of the fabric tape firmly to the plywood. Use the four holes in the plywood.
The design was done in OpenOffice.org draw. The teardrop shape was optimized for carrying maximum loads with minimal stress by a simulation.

print_settings.Notes:: I use a brim with the offset set to 0mm and do 5 passes at one layer thick. The thin end wants to pull up from the bed, so I might add some hold down pads to prevent it from pulling up from the bed.

title: Pen Stand - Microsoft Surface Pen 4 or pretty much any other pen

description.text:
I needed a stand for my pen. I wanted one that could be situated so that picking it up and placing it back in was as close to my neutral hand position as possible while being able to sit it next to my laptop. It also had to be small enough to carry in my bag.

I printed it at .2mm layer height and 20% rectilinear infill. The print I have pictures of is using Verbatim clear ABS. I might modify it to hold an extra battery and possibly the pen tip container that comes with the Surface pen 4. I will leave all of the models for download if I do that.

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I use a brim with the offset set to 0mm and do 5 passes at one layer thick. The thin end wants to pull up from the bed, so I might add some hold down pads to prevent it from pulling up from the bed.

0.2

Infill:

20%

You can see design on OnShape:
https://cad.onshape.com/documents/f896fad8fe083c32cb2862d0/w/4c7cf2585b0d9439472edc9f/e/7244a28929429d9554d2c22a

Multiple extruder update  
I uploaded separate files for the "odd" and "even" spheres to make it easy to print in multiple colors if you have a dual extrusion printer.  
I also separated the supports object so you can include or exclude as you desire, or assign it to a support-material extruder.

v2 Update
Since most printing problems occur at the worst overhangs (closing the vertical circles), I made a second version that includes some support (vs. letting the slicer do it, which generated far too much). This version is the "with supports" file. Oh, and I cracked sphere #2 (second smallest one) snapping in sphere #1 (smallest) into its nib holders; so I also notched the female nibs on one side a bit, which make it a little easer to assemble. I printed the version with supports scaled to 70% that turns out to be just slightly larger than thing 40760. With the supports, I was able to print the object completely unattended. It was easy to break out the bulk of the support, and carve the remainder off with a knife; the smallest sphere was a little tricky to trim off.

After several failed attempts to print thing: 40760 (see photo; yellow), I decided to design my own from scratch.  
The spheres in this version are 5mm thick (less fragile during printing the "vertical" portions), and the "holes" have been cut with a flat inner edge, making the vertically printed holes close at the top better and have a cleaner edge.  
It is also larger overall (to accommodate the thicker spheres); you'll need at least a 150x150x150mm print volume to print it full-size.  
It has nice big nibs with shallow departure angles to avoid any overhang issues.

This can be printed with no support material.  
Printed with PLA on blue painter's tape, extruder @ 180°C, bed at 50°C.  
I printed it with typical 40% honeycomb infill.  I did change the infill angle to 90 degrees, since the solid fills (along the "vertical" rises) are already at 45 degrees relative to the X-Y axes, the 90 degree infill angle makes the fill pattern 45 degrees relative to the part's perimeters up the four rising "corners".  For the circular portions, of course, it makes no difference.  
I also used a 0.75mm Z-lift on retract to avoid hitting anything while making the large fast movements.  Since the print failures I had printing t 40760 were primarily caused by breaking the part (the thin vertical portions) because the tips of the overhang tend to curl up, and the extruder hits one and snaps the part (see photos; yellow).  
I first tried to print it with ABS (see photos; black); that was with a .5mm Z-lift on retract.  
After that failure, I decided to go back to using PLA (as with 40760), with better luck (see photos; orange).  
It still gets dicey at the times where it's closing the vertical circles; I had to babysit and assist the print on the outer 3 spheres.

After printing my own cable chain and getting disappointed with the results, I broke down and bought some Igus cable chain. It's pricey but you know what - you get what you pay for.
I made this little end piece that fits into the hole in the sheet metal that the wires go through. Then I took one of the Igus links and drilled a 2mm hole through it. I bolted it all together and it fits pretty well. The link with the mounting hole is backwards from the rest of the links, but they still fit together. Because of the nut and bolt holding everything securely, my end piece will float a little in the hole.
This fits my xyz davinci 1.0 PRO 3d printer.
This is the chain I bought:
http://www.mcmaster.com/#4409t21/=133dpt2

R1
I made a revision.
It fits a little tighter now, less floating.
I added a small index tab to the back piece so they fit together now.
Overall, just a little bit better now.

Printable version of claw part of MeArm.
Thanks MeArm robotic for bring us such a great product, this new Claw provides a significant increase of torque for grabbing.

As usual, I twisted the original so that :

  1. It use only two types of screws:
    1.1. M3 10mm
    1.2. M3 15mm

  2. Wedged base was include to improve the tolerance of first layer height.

Claw In Action:
https://youtu.be/_st8Y-2w3_g
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LiAk-mW9q_0&feature=youtu.be

This part is a drop-in replacement of the old claw module of MeArm 0.4, so I am not going to transform the whole MeArm Version 1.0 into printable version.

For those who are interested in 3d printing the whole new arm, you may download the parts form my previous thing:
MeArm 0.4 Printable (Re-Organized and Improved)
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1550041

p.s. Sorry for the messy naming, it is a mix of old, new and official part number and names.
But you will find no-difficult to distinguish the part if you refer to the official menu of MeArm V1.0.

ps.ps. Sorry for the color also. I love the Silver fragment in my previous make, but unfortunatly the supplier ran out of that.
